title: Closer's attempt to allocate a small stack doesn't work
body:
Here:
https://github.com/google/guava/blob/34c1616279efe08089960aafd3df486cf8a04820/guava/src/com/google/common/io/Closer.java#L107-L108

In OpenJDK, the minimum size of `ArrayDeque` is 8, so this attempt is worthless.

title: Missing Performance Optimization for toArray of size zero #3209
body: Proof of concept for improving RegularImmutableList's toArray performance.

title: SecureDirectoryStream-based recursive file tree deletion doesn't always work in Docker
body:
I encountered a strange behaviour of `MoreFiles.deleteRecursively()` in a Docker container. It throws a `DirectoryNotEmptyException` at this line: https://github.com/google/guava/blob/34c1616279efe08089960aafd3df486cf8a04820/guava/src/com/google/common/io/MoreFiles.java#L626
It should never happen unless files are concurrently created in the directory, that shouldn't be the case.

I copied the logic of this method, leaving only the "insecure" path, and the problem disappeared.

title: cache.Weigher.weigh() should return a long instead of an int
body:
Currently, the `Weigher.weigh()` returns an `int`. However, setting the maximum cache weight (`.maximumWeight(long weight)`) uses a long. 
```java
public interface Weigher<K, V> {

  /**
   * Returns the weight of a cache entry. There is no unit for entry weights; rather they are simply
   * relative to each other.
   *
   * @return the weight of the entry; must be non-negative
   */
  int weigh(K key, V value);
}

```

**Proposal:**
Weigher#weigh to return a long, instead of an int. A use case would be when caching large files that have a large size in bytes (i.e. a 3gb file) - i understand this is not the main use case of this library.

**Positives:**
- Ability to have item weights that are greater than `Integer.MAX_VALUE`, possibly leading to less silent bugs when weight values are high (and might wraparound to negative)
- Type Parity with the types between `maximumWeight` and `Weigher.weigh()`

**Negatives:**
- Slight performance hit using an int
- Possible to workaround this by rounding or dividing, but thats more difficult

Other options would be more complicated, where this method is initialized using a type of numeric with a default of integer.

title: CaseFormat improvement: Translate accented characters
body:
Docs say explicitly that non ASCII characters are not guaranteed to be upper/lowercased when using CaseFormat. Think it should not be difficult to include special characters from the [Latin](http://www.madore.org/~david/computers/unicode/cstab.html#Latin-1) character set to expand the library coverage beyong English speaking users.
Currently, `CaseFormat.to(CaseFormat.UPPER_CAMEL, "MANÉ")` gives us ManÉ as result.

title: Support for JWTs
body:
I'd love to see JWT support in Guava, Auth0 team has an example java impl that relies on apache commons and jackson. I'd love to see this done with Guava primitives instead and exposed as a proper API from Guava.
https://github.com/auth0/java-jwt/tree/master/lib/src/main/java/com/auth0/jwt

title: Address remaining JSR-305 annotations
body:
The (partial) transition from "JSR-305" nullability annotations to Checker Framework annotations in 23.6 [1] was a welcome change. However, the remaining JSR-305 annotation usages like "package-level" nullability default [2] make it difficult for FindBugs users to use Guava >= 23.6. FindBugs does not recognize the new Checker Qual annotations and so reasons that null-tolerant methods like `ToStringHelper::add(String, @org.checkerframework.checker.nullness.qual.Nullable Object)` are actually null-intolerant.

Given that null-intolerance is the default the Checker type system, and also given the open task [3] to remove the JSR-305 dependency entirely, would Guava consider removing usages of `javax.annotation.ParametersAreNonnullByDefault` and friends in the next release?

[1] https://github.com/google/guava/releases/tag/v23.6
[2] https://github.com/google/guava/blob/master/guava/src/com/google/common/base/package-info.java#L59
[3] https://github.com/google/guava/issues/2960

title: Potential issues with File.length() calls in Files
body: 3 calls to `File.length()` in [`Files`](https://github.com/google/guava/blob/0cd4e9faa1360da4a343f84cb275d6eda0c5e732/guava/src/com/google/common/io/Files.java): in `FileByteSource.sizeIfKnown()`, `FileByteSource.size()` and `Files.map()` might be problematic because they don't check if `File.length()` returns 0 or not, that may signify an I/O error.

title: Please make graphs and graph builders public and non-final
body:
Great library!

I'd like to extend a graph class so as to replace the huge type name it generates with a shorter one more germane to my usage. When a graph gets built, it's type name is something like `MutableValueGraph<SourceElement, SourceRelationship>` whereas I'd like to extend it with a class called `SourceGraph`...much better! The graph builder classes don't allow changes to build a custom graph unless you're happy re-inventing the wheel so it's a case of copy-paste the code just to use the shorter name or use the huge name everywhere.
If the classes were extendable my use case would be very easy.

If there's a good reason not to I don't know it and would love to hear it.

title: Wiki: typo in the CaseFormat example code snippet
body:
I have spotted a small typo in the “CaseFormat” section, in the code snippet: there should be only one closing bracket instead of two.

---

This is a patch for the wiki repository:
```
git clone https://github.com/google/guava.wiki.git
```

Patch:
[patch.diff](https://github.com/google/guava/files/2049421/patch.diff.txt)

---

Is:
 ```java
CaseFormat.UPPER_UNDERSCORE.to(CaseFormat.LOWER_CAMEL, "CONSTANT_NAME")); // returns "constantName"
```

Should be:
 ```java
CaseFormat.UPPER_UNDERSCORE.to(CaseFormat.LOWER_CAMEL, "CONSTANT_NAME"); // returns "constantName"
 ```

title: Possible typos: @javax.annotation.Nullable is only used in two places
body:
There is probably a typo in each of the two following lines of `NullPointerTesterTest`:

https://github.com/google/guava/blob/0a2258e6691a22aa7ff2604871b520d44bbac01f/guava-testlib/test/com/google/common/testing/NullPointerTesterTest.java#L89

https://github.com/google/guava/blob/0a2258e6691a22aa7ff2604871b520d44bbac01f/guava-testlib/test/com/google/common/testing/NullPointerTesterTest.java#L553

They use `@javax.annotation.Nullable`, but all other `@Nullable` uses seem to be `@org.checkerframework.checker.nullness.qual.Nullable`.

title: BiFunction separator provider for Joiner
body:
I have a use case for `Joiner` where the separator must be obtained from the next part to be joined.  I can imagine situations where the separator must be obtained from the previous part to be joined, or from some logic operating on both the previous and the next parts.

Would you consider allowing a `BiFunction<T, T, String>` to be a separator provider, where the previous part is the first argument, the next part is the second argument, and the return value is the separator?

This would require either having `Joiner<T>`, or casting within a raw-type or wildcard `BiFunction`.

If this were implemented, I'd imagine that `MapJoiner` should support an analogous key separator provider, too.

Some changes to the Guava README. Move most information about the latest release to the release badge at the top, which now links to the GitHub release page for the latest release and automatically displays the latest release version number. Note: I probably would have removed explicit references to the latest version number entirely (meaning no changes to it need to be made when a new release is created) except for the fact that the release process currently relies on there being *some* change made when prepare_release is run so that the release script knows what commit to create the release from. There are ways we could deal with that, but I didn't want to deal with that yet. 0f364779d314470c8855a6c0c805f858ed418c65 -------

title: Use api instead of compile for Android
Put @NullableDecl last in lists of annotations
body:
Conceptially, `@NullableDecl` is a type annotation (one day, Guava may be changed to use a type annotation instead), so it makes sense to put it as close as possible to where it would appear as a type annotation.  That means putting it last in lists of declaration annotations, closest to the return type.

This pull request makes that change.

title: PatternCompiler should have public modifier
body:
At the moment, we are trying to modularize guava on the fly before linking with jlink.

In order to use modular JAR in the future PatternCompiler must have public modifier.

Otherwise: ServiceLoader throws exception - java.util.ServiceConfigurationError: com.google.common.base.PatternCompiler: module com.google.common does not declare `uses`

Also, we cannot define "uses" in module-info.java for com.google.common.base.PatternCompiler:
```
~/com.google.common/module-info.java:27: error: PatternCompiler is not public in com.google.common.base; cannot be accessed from outside package
uses com.google.common.base.PatternCompiler;
```

Solution: define com.google.common.base.PatternCompiler as public, any way, split packages are not allowed in modular environment

title: Put type annotations on types, not declarations
body: To improve readability, the Java Language Specification recommends that type annotations are written "immediately before the type to which they apply" (https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-9.html#jls-9.7.4).  This pull request makes Guava conform to that style guideline.

title: Javadoc for Multimaps.unmodifiableMultimap is misleading
body:
The Javadoc for [Multimaps.unmodifiableMultimap](https://github.com/google/guava/blob/7abf5990b29f19a7e8c458b63af73c88523e1820/android/guava/src/com/google/common/collect/Multimaps.java#L517-L518) (as well as the other `Multimaps.unmodifiable*Multimap implementations`) include this note: ``` *

Note that the generated multimap's {@link Multimap#removeAll} and {@link * Multimap#replaceValues} methods return collections that are modifiable. ``` In all of these implementations the `removeAll` and `replaceValues` methods simply throw an `UnsupportedOperationException`, not returning anything much less a modifiable collection.

title: collect: add Sets#newSingleElementSet
body:
In many situations APIs force to use Set, where only a single element is
required. Such use cases can be covered by Sets#newHashSet(element).
However, if we know in advance that this is an immutable Set with a
single element a more efficient implementation can be used.

Add a new Sets#newSingleElementSet method to create a lightweight Set
to store a single element.

title: InternetDomainName.topPrivateDomain() Fails on Suffix .site
body:
I have the following code:

```
private static String getDomainName(final String url) throws MalformedURLException {
     final URL u = new URL(url);
    return InternetDomainName.from(u.getHost()).topPrivateDomain().toString();
}
```

The String `http://opticafsm.business.site/` is what's passed to `getDomainName()`.

Unfortunately, it results in the error

```
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Not under a public suffix: opticafsm.business.site
	at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkState(Preconditions.java:177)
	at com.google.common.net.InternetDomainName.topPrivateDomain(InternetDomainName.java:447)
	at Links.getDomainName(Links.java:119)
```

The version of Guava being used was, original, version 16 which I thought might be causing the issue but, after upgrading to 24.1-jre, the behavior didn't change in any way.

It seems that it's not recognizing `.site` as a public suffix in spite of being listed here: https://publicsuffix.org/list/public_suffix_list.dat

```
// site : 2015-01-15 DotSite Inc.
site
```

which causes `topPrivateDomain()` to fail, when it's called.

title: Use @SafeVarargs annotation for Sets#cartesianProduct
body:
We already had `@SafeVarargs` annotation for `Lists.cartesianProduct(List<? extends B>... lists`. but `Sets.cartesianProduct(Set<? extends B>... sets) ` was missing this annotation so i have added that annotation in order to fix issue.
Fixes #2724

title: Moe Sync
body:
This code has been reviewed and submitted internally. Feel free to discuss on the PR and we can submit follow-up changes as necessary. Commits: =====

Fix toString of NonSerializableMemoizingSupplier Fixes #3107 9185822ee16cdd641657c0f8e7ead755c9e9a564 -------

Use Splitter instead of String.split, in InternetDomainName. e56f1aa3d21b04eed8f5481d4103c05af5c51ec7 -------

Use Splitter for IPv6, too. This eliminates usage of java.util.regex from this file (which is used via String.split, otherwise). 65a2a7de4ef4eea913f769a5cbbce6e35e1fccce -------

Automated rollback of a12ef6b46b26fe178021c099e3db6a8a99f5174e. It looks like the original change can cause an infinite loop in LocalCache.LoadingValueReference.get(). c2266a6ff8c6f298673688d6779b8b7368fe9147 -------

Don't enable use of Unsafe.getLong() on aarch64 devices. Android devices may report to run aarch64 while running in 32-bit mode, and then crash when loading 64-bit values at unaligned addresses. 263bbcf6cf0cfae6768ddf9e9f3d749da555e422

title: InetAddresses support for IPv4 addr containing netmask
body:
The InetAddresses class does not seem to support IPv4 addresses containing CIDR netmask (like /24)
Example:
InetAddresses.isInetAddress("192.168.2.0/24") returns false, while this should be considered valid and return true.
Please look into it. Thanks.

title: Small mistake in precondition check example
body:
```java
checkArgument(i < j, "Expected i < j, but %s > %s", i, j);
```

should be  
```java
checkArgument(i < j, "Expected i < j, but %s >= %s", i, j);
```

😉 🤓

title: InternetDomainName.findSuffixOfType() in junit test returns java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: EXACT
body:
I'm using guava `24.1-jre` and jdk `1.8.0.162`

```
InternetDomainName.from("google.com");
```

causes

```
java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: EXACT

	at com.google.common.net.InternetDomainName.findSuffixOfType(InternetDomainName.java:172)
	at com.google.common.net.InternetDomainName.<init>(InternetDomainName.java:153)
	at com.google.common.net.InternetDomainName.from(InternetDomainName.java:212)
	at com.dnb.vici.formfill.common.UtilFunctions.getCustomerAndDomainId(UtilFunctions.java:73)
	at com.dnb.vici.formfill.ut.UtilFunctionsTest.getCustomerAndDomainIdTest(UtilFunctionsTest.java:73)
```

It's failing on [InternetDomainName.java Line #172](https://github.com/google/guava/blob/26b09c1fd30c23bc0e48701ff7131f2de1e5fe35/guava/src/com/google/common/net/InternetDomainName.java#L172) and this [old storm issue](https://www.mail-archive.com/search?l=dev@storm.apache.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bjira%5C%5D+%5C%5BUpdated%5C%5D+%5C(STORM%5C-538%5C)+Guava+com.google.thirdparty.publicsuffix+is+not+shaded%22&o=newest&f=1) returns a very similar error.

In IntelliJ when I evaluate the expression, it returns `false` as expected but running through the code will throw the exception and it only happens during a unit test... Why does this happen?

title: Fix toString of NonSerializableMemoizingSupplier
body: Delegate is set to null once the value has been computed, but is still referenced by the toString method. When it's null, use the value instead.

title: Add some "dangerous" APIs
body: It would be nice if guava added some "dangerous" APIs e.g. for starting/running/managing processes, because [ppl keep using guava wrong](https://github.com/MovingBlocks/Terasology/issues/2791) and we should do something about it.

title: LoadingCache code example has issues
KD Trees and QuadTrees
body: I have noticed that there is no implementation of QuadTree or KDTree. These structures can be in fact very helpful in searching dimensional spaces. Any ideas on implementing these structures? I think this would be great addition to Guava.

title: Commenting testcase that does not compile
Adds Overloaded Methods to CacheBuilder
body:
Address #2999
I have overloaded the methods listed in the issue so that they accept Duration as a parameter. One function I couldn't quite implement without a bunch of additional code was if the value was negative the error message would return the value + the unit. I cut the unit variable out and replaced it with nanoseconds. The value is also converted to nano.

title: cleanup cache when read cache
body: As I Know,`postReadCleanup(); `will be called when read cache ;and will call `cleanUp();` when read count reach 64; But it just clean the expired cache that we read the key? Whether the 'read CleanUp' just clean what we read that cache?   Others' expired cache will be kept util we write/read it or call `Cache.cleanUp()`?
